title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 9
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: How often and willingly do I not look again in fancy on Tummel, orManor, or the talking Airdle, or Dee swirling in its Lynn; on the brightburn of Kinnaird, or the golden burn that pours and sulks in the denbehind Kingussie! I think shame to leave out one of these enchantresses,but the list would grow too long if I remembered all; only I may notforget Allan Water, nor birch-wetting Rogie, nor yet Almond; nor, forall its pollutions, that Water of Leith of the many and well-namedmills--Bell's Mills, and Canon Mills, and Silver Mills; nor Redford Burnof pleasant memories; nor yet, for all its smallness, that namelesstrickle that springs in the green bosom of Allermuir, and is fed fromHalkerside with a perennial teacupful, and threads the moss under theShearer's Knowe, and makes one pool there, overhung by a rock, where Iloved to sit and make bad verses, and is then kidnapped in its infancyby subterranean pipes for the service of the sea-beholding city in theplain.

title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: About an hour ago did we, standing on the very beautiful bridjre of Perth, see that identical salmon, with his back-fin just visible above the transhioent tide, arrowing up the Tay, bold as a bridegroom, and nothing doubting that lie should spend his honeymoon among the gravel-beds of Kinnaird or Moulineam, or the rocky sofas of the Tummel, or the green marble couches of the Tilt.

title: Diary, reminiscences, and correspondence of Henry Crabb Robinson ...
author: Robinson, Henry Crabb
snippet: His absence from the poll, the folly of his committee in joining with Kinnaird, — and even the secession of the few who have split their votes for Cartwright and Hunt, will, I expect,  in concurrence with the decided hostility of the Court, and the semi- opposition of the Whigs, six Captain Maxwell as second to Romilly.

title: Memoirs, journal, and correspondence of Thomas Moore.
author: Moore, Thomas
snippet: I found Beaujolois at the Duke of Athol's, whence we adjourned to Inverary ; there William Lamb *, and Kinnaird, Lord Lornef, my sister, the Campbells, and numerous other people were assembled ; and we contrived to keep up such a continual riot, that I changed the name of Inverary  to that of Confusion Castle, with universal approbation.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: My wife's grandfather, I can still recollect, died September 20, 1823, aged near sixty-six ; I was at Kinnaird (BuUer's in Perthshire),  and had it in a letter from her : letters from her were almost the sole light-points in my dreary miseries there (fruit of miserable health mainly, and of a future blank and barred to me, as I felt).

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: I finished it the next spring, not at Kinnaird but at Mainhill.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: My two rooms were in the old "Mansion" of Kinnaird, some three or four hundred yards from the new, and on a lower level, overshadowed with wood.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Martiu of Kirkcaldy now become Ms life-partner ; off on a tour to the Highlands ; and the generous soul had determined to pass near Kinnaird (right hank of Tay, a mile below the junction of Tummel and Tay), where I then was with the Bullers, and pick me up to accompany  as far as I would.

title: Gray Days and Gold ... New edition, revised, with illustrations
author: Winter, William
snippet: Kinnaird liesto the eastward, while northward a little way is the famous field of Bannockburn.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: 2 " The ten who signed the Memorial were Lords Errol,Panmure, Stormont, and Kinnaird; Ogilvie of Bovnc, Morayof Abercairnie, N. Keith, for the Earl Marischall, CrummondofLogie, Fotheringham of Pourie, and Innes of Coxtoun."-Ibid., p.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: and Kinnaird ; Opilvie of Borne, -fontsof Abercaimie, N. Keith, for the Earl Marischall.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: It was at Merchiston Hall that my father metmany distinguished men—among others Bruce ofKinnaird, the Abyssinian traveller, whom he spokeof as a very tall, handsome, well-built man, butdistant and reserved.
